title: How to Make a Butterfly Hair Bow

methods.name: Making a Simple Butterfly Hair Bow

steps.headline: Cut two pieces of ⅞-inch (22-millimeter) grosgrain ribbon.
steps.description: Your first piece needs to be 3½ inches (8.89 centimeters) long, and your second piece needs to be 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) long. You can use a solid colored ribbon for this, but a pattern (such as polka dot) would look nicer. This will make the wings. Grosgrain ribbon is different from satin ribbon. It is not shiny and it has a bumpy/ribbed texture.

steps.headline: Cut the wing ribbon at an angle.
steps.description: Fold both wing ribbons in half, widthwise. Match up the ends, then cut them at an angle. Unfold the ribbons when you are done.

steps.headline: Cut a short piece of ⅜-inch (9-millimeter) grosgrain ribbon.
steps.description: The ribbon only needs to be between 1½ and 2 inches (2.54 and 5.08 centimeters) long. Use a solid color for this. This will make the body. Choose a color that goes well with your wider ribbon. For example, if you are using a pink ribbon with white polka dots for the wings, choose a white ribbon for the body.

steps.headline: Cut a 2½ (6.35-centimeter) piece of ⅛-inch (3-millimeter) ribbon.
steps.description: This will make the antenna. Use the same color as your body ribbon.

steps.headline: Heat seal the ribbons for a cleaner finish.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it is highly recommended. Not only will this make your butterfly look neater, but it will keep the ribbons from fraying. Light a candle or turn on a lighter. Hold each cut end of the ribbons over the flame for a few seconds until the ends melt slightly. Do not let the ribbons burn, however. Keep a bowl or cup of water nearby, just in case.

steps.headline: Sew a running stitch down the center of a wing ribbon, widthwise.
steps.description:
Fold a wing ribbon in half widthwise. Pinch the fold to make a crease, then unfold the ribbon. Thread your needle and tie a knot at the end. Sew a simple running stitch along the crease
Work on one wing ribbon at a time.

steps.headline: Pull the thread to gather the ribbon.
steps.description: This will help create the wing shapes for your butterfly. Do not cut the thread yet.

steps.headline: Wrap the thread around the center of the wing ribbon, then tie it in a knot.
steps.description: Keep the wing ribbon gathered with one hand, and use your other hand to wrap the thread around it a few times. Pull the needle under the wrapped thread, then push it back through the loop. Make a second similar knot, then snip off the excess thread.

steps.headline: Stitch, gather, and knot your second wing.
steps.description: Find the center of your second wing ribbon. Make a running stitch down the center, widthwise. Pull the thread to gather it. Wrap the thread around the wing a few times. Knot the thread to itself, then snip off the excess.

steps.headline: Position the wings.
steps.description: Place the wings side by side, with the long edges touching. Place the longer wing on top and the shorter wing on the bottom. Make sure that the cut angles are sloping inward towards the joint to create > and < shapes. Make sure that the patterned side is facing you.

steps.headline: Stitch the wings together.
steps.description: Thread your needle and tie a knot at the end. Push the needle up through the center of the bottom ribbon and out through the top ribbon. Wrap the thread around the center of both ribbons a few times. Tie the thread off, then sniff the excess. For a neater finish, flip the butterfly over, then make two small stitches to either side of the center thread, joining the wings together.

steps.headline: Place the body ribbon behind the center of your butterfly.
steps.description: Set the body ribbon down on your work surface. Orient it vertically. Flip your butterfly over so that the back is facing you. Set it down on top of the body ribbon. Make it centered.

steps.headline: Wrap the body ribbon around the butterfly.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the back of the butterfly. Pull the bottom of the body ribbon up and press it into the glue. Cut off the excess ribbon. Place another drop of glue on the back of the butterfly. Pull the top part of the body ribbon down and press it into the glue. Snip off the excess ribbon.

steps.headline: Fold the antenna ribbon in half and attach it to the back of the butterfly.
steps.description: Fold the antenna in half to make a V-shape. Place it on the back of the butterfly, with the ends sticking out over the top of the longer ribbon. Secure the antenna with a few stitches or with a drop of hot glue.

steps.headline: Hot glue the butterfly to a hairclip.
steps.description:
Hot glue a narrow, matching ribbon over the top of a hairclip and snip off the excess. Draw a horizontal line across the back of the butterfly, using the joint between the wings as a guide. Press the butterfly against the hairclip. If you wish to attach the butterfly to a hair tie, do the following:
Cut a small circle out of felt, about the same size as the butterfly's center. Cover the circle with hot glue. Place the circle against the inside of a hair tie. Make sure that the hair tie is centered across it. Press the butterfly into the glue. Orient it horizontally.

methods.name: Making a Fancy Butterfly Hair Bow

steps.headline: Cut your ribbons.
steps.description:
Measure and cut your ribbon according to the list below. Grosgrain ribbon works the best for this project, but you can use satin ribbon as well. Wings: 24 inches (60.96 centimeters) of 1 1/2-inch (38-millimeter) patterned ribbon
Body: 6 inches (cc centimeters) of ⅞-inch (22-millimeter) solid-colored ribbon
Hairclip cover: 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) of ⅜-inch (9-millimeter) solid-colored ribbon

steps.headline: Heat seal the ends, if desired.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it will give your butterfly a neater finish. Light a candle or lighter. Hold the ribbon ends over the flame for a few seconds until they melt. Don't let the ribbon burn. Keep a bowl or cup of water nearby, just in case.

steps.headline: Fold the wing ribbon in half to find the center.
steps.description: Make a crease or mark it with a pen or sewing pin.

steps.headline: Twist and fold the left end towards the center.
steps.description: Set the wing ribbon down on your work surface with the wrong side facing you. Pull the left end towards the center. Twist the end upwards and pin it just past the center of the ribbon. When you are done, your ribbon should have a loop. The right side of the ribbon should be touching the wrong side.

steps.headline: Twist and fold the right end towards the center.
steps.description: This time, twist the end downwards. Pin the end of the ribbon just past the center so that it is overlapping the left end. This will create a figure-8 or infinity-symbol shape. You still want the right side of the ribbon to be touching the wrong side. It is very important that you overlap the ribbon ends, or the butterfly won't hold together.

steps.headline: Bring the left loop towards the center.
steps.description: Take the tip of the left loop and bring it towards the center of the ribbon. Pin it in place, with the wrong side facing down and the right side facing up.

steps.headline: Bring the right loop towards the center.
steps.description: Use the same technique as you did for the left loop. Overlap the two loops slightly, and secure them with pins. When you are done, you should have something like looks like a square with a loop at each corner. It's important to overlap the loops, or the butterfly will fall apart.

steps.headline: Make a running stitch down the center.
steps.description: Thread your needle, and tie a knot at the center. Sew a simple running stitch down the center of the butterfly. Remove the pins when you are done, but do not cut the thread.

steps.headline: Gather the butterfly.
steps.description: Gently pull on the thread until the ribbon starts to gather. Wrap the thread a few times around the middle of the butterfly, then tie it off. Snip off the excess thread.

steps.headline: Tie a knot in the center of your body ribbon.
steps.description: Simply bring both ends towards the center and cross them over to make a loop. Slide one of the ends through the loop. Gently tug on both ends to make a knot.

steps.headline: Glue the body to the center of the butterfly.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the center of the butterfly. Press the knotted body into the glue. Make sure that it is oriented vertically. Use the stitching line as a guide.

steps.headline: Trim the body ribbon down.
steps.description: Flip the butterfly over so that the back is facing you. Trim the ends of the body down to 1/2 to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.08 centimeters).

steps.headline: Glue the ends of the ribbon down onto the back of the butterfly.
steps.description: Place a drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly. Pull the bottom ribbon up and press it into the glue. Place another drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly. Pull the top ribbon down and press it into the glue, overlapping the bottom one.

steps.headline: Glue the hairclip cover ribbon to an alligator clip.
steps.description: Draw line of glue down your final ribbon. Clamp the hairclip over it; the ribbon will extend part the tip of the clip. Fold the ribbon over the top of the clip, and press it down.

steps.headline: Glue the butterfly to the clip.
steps.description: Draw a horizontal line of hot glue along the back of the butterfly. Press the butterfly against the hairclip and let the glue set.

tyn: Hot glue gun and hot glue sticks
Candle or lighter (optional, for heat sealing)
text:
Making a Simple Butterfly Hair Bow Cut two pieces of ⅞-inch (22-millimeter) grosgrain ribbon. Your first piece needs to be 3½ inches (8.89 centimeters) long, and your second piece needs to be 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) long. You can use a solid colored ribbon for this, but a pattern (such as polka dot) would look nicer. This will make the wings. Grosgrain ribbon is different from satin ribbon. It is not shiny and it has a bumpy/ribbed texture. Cut the wing ribbon at an angle. Fold both wing ribbons in half, widthwise. Match up the ends, then cut them at an angle. Unfold the ribbons when you are done. Cut a short piece of ⅜-inch (9-millimeter) grosgrain ribbon. The ribbon only needs to be between 1½ and 2 inches (2.54 and 5.08 centimeters) long. Use a solid color for this. This will make the body. Choose a color that goes well with your wider ribbon. For example, if you are using a pink ribbon with white polka dots for the wings, choose a white ribbon for the body. Cut a 2½ (6.35-centimeter) piece of ⅛-inch (3-millimeter) ribbon. This will make the antenna. Use the same color as your body ribbon. Heat seal the ribbons for a cleaner finish. This is not completely necessary, but it is highly recommended. Not only will this make your butterfly look neater, but it will keep the ribbons from fraying. Light a candle or turn on a lighter. Hold each cut end of the ribbons over the flame for a few seconds until the ends melt slightly. Do not let the ribbons burn, however. Keep a bowl or cup of water nearby, just in case. Sew a running stitch down the center of a wing ribbon, widthwise. Fold a wing ribbon in half widthwise. Pinch the fold to make a crease, then unfold the ribbon. Thread your needle and tie a knot at the end. Sew a simple running stitch along the crease
Work on one wing ribbon at a time. Pull the thread to gather the ribbon. This will help create the wing shapes for your butterfly. Do not cut the thread yet. Wrap the thread around the center of the wing ribbon, then tie it in a knot. Keep the wing ribbon gathered with one hand, and use your other hand to wrap the thread around it a few times. Pull the needle under the wrapped thread, then push it back through the loop. Make a second similar knot, then snip off the excess thread. Stitch, gather, and knot your second wing. Find the center of your second wing ribbon. Make a running stitch down the center, widthwise. Pull the thread to gather it. Wrap the thread around the wing a few times. Knot the thread to itself, then snip off the excess. Position the wings. Place the wings side by side, with the long edges touching. Place the longer wing on top and the shorter wing on the bottom. Make sure that the cut angles are sloping inward towards the joint to create > and < shapes. Make sure that the patterned side is facing you. Stitch the wings together. Thread your needle and tie a knot at the end. Push the needle up through the center of the bottom ribbon and out through the top ribbon. Wrap the thread around the center of both ribbons a few times. Tie the thread off, then sniff the excess. For a neater finish, flip the butterfly over, then make two small stitches to either side of the center thread, joining the wings together. Place the body ribbon behind the center of your butterfly. Set the body ribbon down on your work surface. Orient it vertically. Flip your butterfly over so that the back is facing you. Set it down on top of the body ribbon. Make it centered. Wrap the body ribbon around the butterfly. Place a drop of hot glue on the back of the butterfly. Pull the bottom of the body ribbon up and press it into the glue. Cut off the excess ribbon. Place another drop of glue on the back of the butterfly. Pull the top part of the body ribbon down and press it into the glue. Snip off the excess ribbon. Fold the antenna ribbon in half and attach it to the back of the butterfly. Fold the antenna in half to make a V-shape. Place it on the back of the butterfly, with the ends sticking out over the top of the longer ribbon. Secure the antenna with a few stitches or with a drop of hot glue. Hot glue the butterfly to a hairclip. Hot glue a narrow, matching ribbon over the top of a hairclip and snip off the excess. Draw a horizontal line across the back of the butterfly, using the joint between the wings as a guide. Press the butterfly against the hairclip. If you wish to attach the butterfly to a hair tie, do the following:
Cut a small circle out of felt, about the same size as the butterfly's center. Cover the circle with hot glue. Place the circle against the inside of a hair tie. Make sure that the hair tie is centered across it. Press the butterfly into the glue. Orient it horizontally. Making a Fancy Butterfly Hair Bow Cut your ribbons. Measure and cut your ribbon according to the list below. Grosgrain ribbon works the best for this project, but you can use satin ribbon as well. Wings: 24 inches (60.96 centimeters) of 1 1/2-inch (38-millimeter) patterned ribbon
Body: 6 inches (cc centimeters) of ⅞-inch (22-millimeter) solid-colored ribbon
Hairclip cover: 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) of ⅜-inch (9-millimeter) solid-colored ribbon Heat seal the ends, if desired. This is not completely necessary, but it will give your butterfly a neater finish. Light a candle or lighter. Hold the ribbon ends over the flame for a few seconds until they melt. Don't let the ribbon burn. Keep a bowl or cup of water nearby, just in case. Fold the wing ribbon in half to find the center. Make a crease or mark it with a pen or sewing pin. Twist and fold the left end towards the center. Set the wing ribbon down on your work surface with the wrong side facing you. Pull the left end towards the center. Twist the end upwards and pin it just past the center of the ribbon. When you are done, your ribbon should have a loop. The right side of the ribbon should be touching the wrong side. Twist and fold the right end towards the center. This time, twist the end downwards. Pin the end of the ribbon just past the center so that it is overlapping the left end. This will create a figure-8 or infinity-symbol shape. You still want the right side of the ribbon to be touching the wrong side. It is very important that you overlap the ribbon ends, or the butterfly won't hold together. Bring the left loop towards the center. Take the tip of the left loop and bring it towards the center of the ribbon. Pin it in place, with the wrong side facing down and the right side facing up. Bring the right loop towards the center. Use the same technique as you did for the left loop. Overlap the two loops slightly, and secure them with pins. When you are done, you should have something like looks like a square with a loop at each corner. It's important to overlap the loops, or the butterfly will fall apart. Make a running stitch down the center. Thread your needle, and tie a knot at the center. Sew a simple running stitch down the center of the butterfly. Remove the pins when you are done, but do not cut the thread. Gather the butterfly. Gently pull on the thread until the ribbon starts to gather. Wrap the thread a few times around the middle of the butterfly, then tie it off. Snip off the excess thread. Tie a knot in the center of your body ribbon. Simply bring both ends towards the center and cross them over to make a loop. Slide one of the ends through the loop. Gently tug on both ends to make a knot. Glue the body to the center of the butterfly. Place a drop of hot glue on the center of the butterfly. Press the knotted body into the glue. Make sure that it is oriented vertically. Use the stitching line as a guide. Trim the body ribbon down. Flip the butterfly over so that the back is facing you. Trim the ends of the body down to 1/2 to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.08 centimeters). Glue the ends of the ribbon down onto the back of the butterfly. Place a drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly. Pull the bottom ribbon up and press it into the glue. Place another drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly. Pull the top ribbon down and press it into the glue, overlapping the bottom one. Glue the hairclip cover ribbon to an alligator clip. Draw line of glue down your final ribbon. Clamp the hairclip over it; the ribbon will extend part the tip of the clip. Fold the ribbon over the top of the clip, and press it down. Glue the butterfly to the clip. Draw a horizontal line of hot glue along the back of the butterfly. Press the butterfly against the hairclip and let the glue set.

Your first piece needs to be 3½ inches (8.89 centimeters) long, and your second piece needs to be 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) long.
You can use a solid colored ribbon for this, but a pattern (such as polka dot) would look nicer.
This will make the wings.
Grosgrain ribbon is different from satin ribbon.
It is not shiny and it has a bumpy/ribbed texture.
Cut the wing ribbon at an angle.

Match up the ends, then cut them at an angle.
Unfold the ribbons when you are done.
Cut a short piece of ⅜-inch (9-millimeter) grosgrain ribbon.
The ribbon only needs to be between 1½ and 2 inches (2.54 and 5.08 centimeters) long.
Use a solid color for this.
This will make the body.
Choose a color that goes well with your wider ribbon.
For example, if you are using a pink ribbon with white polka dots for the wings, choose a white ribbon for the body.
Cut a 2½ (6.35-centimeter) piece of ⅛-inch (3-millimeter) ribbon.
This will make the antenna.
Use the same color as your body ribbon.
Heat seal the ribbons for a cleaner finish.
This is not completely necessary, but it is highly recommended.
Not only will this make your butterfly look neater, but it will keep the ribbons from fraying.

Do not let the ribbons burn, however.
Keep a bowl or cup of water nearby, just in case.

This will help create the wing shapes for your butterfly.
Do not cut the thread yet.

Knot the thread to itself, then snip off the excess.
Position the wings.
Place the wings side by side, with the long edges touching.
Place the longer wing on top and the shorter wing on the bottom.
Make sure that the cut angles are sloping inward towards the joint to create > and < shapes.
Make sure that the patterned side is facing you.

Thread your needle and tie a knot at the end.

Wrap the thread around the center of both ribbons a few times.
Tie the thread off, then sniff the excess.
For a neater finish, flip the butterfly over, then make two small stitches to either side of the center thread, joining the wings together.
Place the body ribbon behind the center of your butterfly.
Set the body ribbon down on your work surface.
Orient it vertically.
Flip your butterfly over so that the back is facing you.
Set it down on top of the body ribbon.
Make it centered.
Wrap the body ribbon around the butterfly.
Place a drop of hot glue on the back of the butterfly.
Pull the bottom of the body ribbon up and press it into the glue.
Cut off the excess ribbon.
Place another drop of glue on the back of the butterfly.
Pull the top part of the body ribbon down and press it into the glue.
Snip off the excess ribbon.
Fold the antenna ribbon in half and attach it to the back of the butterfly.
Fold the antenna in half to make a V-shape.
Place it on the back of the butterfly, with the ends sticking out over the top of the longer ribbon.
Secure the antenna with a few stitches or with a drop of hot glue.
Hot glue the butterfly to a hairclip.
Hot glue a narrow, matching ribbon over the top of a hairclip and snip off the excess.
Draw a horizontal line across the back of the butterfly, using the joint between the wings as a guide.

If you wish to attach the butterfly to a hair tie, do the following:
Cut a small circle out of felt, about the same size as the butterfly's center.
Cover the circle with hot glue.
Place the circle against the inside of a hair tie.
Make sure that the hair tie is centered across it.
Press the butterfly into the glue.
Orient it horizontally.

Grosgrain ribbon works the best for this project, but you can use satin ribbon as well.

Body: 6 inches (cc centimeters) of ⅞-inch (22-millimeter) solid-colored ribbon

When you are done, you should have something like looks like a square with a loop at each corner.
It's important to overlap the loops, or the butterfly will fall apart.
Make a running stitch down the center.
Thread your needle, and tie a knot at the center.
Sew a simple running stitch down the center of the butterfly.
Remove the pins when you are done, but do not cut the thread.
Gather the butterfly.
Gently pull on the thread until the ribbon starts to gather.

Tie a knot in the center of your body ribbon.
Simply bring both ends towards the center and cross them over to make a loop.
Slide one of the ends through the loop.
Gently tug on both ends to make a knot.
Glue the body to the center of the butterfly.
Place a drop of hot glue on the center of the butterfly.
Press the knotted body into the glue.
Make sure that it is oriented vertically.
Use the stitching line as a guide.

Flip the butterfly over so that the back is facing you.
Trim the ends of the body down to 1/2 to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.08 centimeters).
Glue the ends of the ribbon down onto the back of the butterfly.
Place a drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly.
Pull the bottom ribbon up and press it into the glue.
Place another drop of glue onto the back of the butterfly.
Pull the top ribbon down and press it into the glue, overlapping the bottom one.
Glue the hairclip cover ribbon to an alligator clip.
Draw line of glue down your final ribbon.
Clamp the hairclip over it; the ribbon will extend part the tip of the clip.
Fold the ribbon over the top of the clip, and press it down.
Glue the butterfly to the clip.
Draw a horizontal line of hot glue along the back of the butterfly.
Press the butterfly against the hairclip and let the glue set.
